sourcesContent:
import React, { useState } from 'react'; import { useProgress } from '../../contexts/ProgressContext'; const DatabaseFundamentals = () => { const { markTopicComplete } = useProgress(); const [completed, setCompleted] = useState(false); const [activeTab, setActiveTab] = useState('intro'); const tabs = [ { id: 'intro', name: 'Introduction' }, { id: 'types', name: 'DBMS Types' }, { id: 'architecture', name: 'Architecture' }, { id: 'advantages', name: 'Advantages' } ]; return (

Database Fundamentals & Architecture

Learn the basics of databases, their architecture, types, and key concepts

{/* Tab Navigation */}
{tabs.map((tab) => ( ))}
{/* Introduction Tab */} {activeTab === 'intro' && (

What is a Database?

Definition:

A database is an organized collection of structured information, or data, typically stored electronically in a computer system. A database is usually controlled by a database management system (DBMS).

Key Characteristics:

  • • Persistent storage of data
  • • Efficient data retrieval
  • • Data sharing among multiple users
  • • Data integrity and security
  • • Concurrent access control

Database vs File System:

Aspect File System Database
Data Organization Unstructured files Structured tables
Data Sharing Limited Multiple users
Security Basic OS security Advanced DBMS security
)} {/* DBMS Types Tab */} {activeTab === 'types' && (

Types of Database Management Systems

Relational DBMS (RDBMS)

Organizes data into tables with rows and columns. Uses SQL for data manipulation.

Examples: MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, SQL Server

NoSQL Databases

Non-relational databases for unstructured or semi-structured data.

Document: MongoDB, CouchDB
Key-Value: Redis, DynamoDB
Graph: Neo4j, Amazon Neptune
Column-family: Cassandra, HBase

Object-Oriented DBMS

Stores data as objects, similar to object-oriented programming.

Examples: db4o, Versant

Hierarchical & Network DBMS

Older models with tree-like (hierarchical) or graph-like (network) structures.

Examples: IBM IMS (Hierarchical)
)} {/* Architecture Tab */} {activeTab === 'architecture' && (

Database Architecture

Three-Level Architecture

External Level

User view of the database. Different users see different perspectives.

Conceptual Level

Logical structure of entire database. Community view of data.

Internal Level

Physical storage structure. How data is actually stored on disk.

Data Independence

Physical Data Independence

Changes in physical storage structure don't affect conceptual level.

Example: Changing storage device or file organization

Logical Data Independence

Changes in conceptual schema don't affect external schemas.

Example: Adding/removing tables or columns
)} {/* Advantages Tab */} {activeTab === 'advantages' && (

Advantages of Database Approach

Controlled Redundancy

Minimizes data duplication through normalization and centralized management.

Data Consistency

Ensures uniform data values and reduces inconsistencies through constraints.

Data Security

Provides authentication, authorization, and access control mechanisms.

Concurrent Access

Allows multiple users to access data simultaneously with proper locking.

Data Integrity

Maintains accuracy and reliability through constraints and validation rules.

Backup and Recovery

Provides automated backup and recovery mechanisms for data protection.

Additional Benefits:

  • • Efficient Query Processing: Optimized query execution and indexing
  • • Data Sharing: Multiple applications can access same data
  • • Standards Compliance: Follows industry standards like SQL
  • • Scalability: Can handle growing amounts of data and users
  • • Maintenance: Centralized administration and monitoring
)}
); }; export default DatabaseFundamentals;
